I did not think of this but it's a really good point. As regional climate changes, the species which occupy the region are likely to change as well.</p>

<p>We could see a change in where certain species could be found. For example, more recently I have heard about the expansion of the wild boar populations. They used to be only found in the southernmost states but are gradually making their way further north as temperatures warm and winters become less variable.</p>
<p>If the earth has gotten warmer, you would expect to see polar bears have shorter hunting periods since ice is present for a shorter amount of time than in the past. </p>
<p>I agree that species extinction is a long term effect and that it could show the warming of the earths biosphere </p>

<p>One example of earth warming is the global changes in species populations, including some extinctions. This is an example of a long term effect of climate changes. As the earth warms and climate change effects are felt, some species will eventually be unable to adapt to new conditions causing population loss and/or extinction.</p>

<p>I agree that changes in the carbon cycle is a good example to show that the earth is getting warmer. I believe that this would be over centuries. </p>

<p>If the Earth has gotten warmer, we would expect to see certain sea life that require cooler ocean temperatures to have a diminishing habitat range as oceans warm. This would be a more recent decades effect.</p>

<p>Increases in fires and draught in recent years due to climate change has had negative effects on plants. In draughts plants will need more water to survive but when they dont get that they may die. Increases in the death of plants, which absorb carbon dioxide, means more carbon dioxide is released. I would say this is more of a recent effect because of all the increases in fires recently. </p>
<p>I think it could also be an example of a very extreme ice age, but would be an example of climate change for sure.</p>

There are so many animal behavior changes that could be a result.</p>
<p>long term</p>

<p>One example I can think of for increasing climate change is the more recent appearance of polar bear/brown bear hybrids in the wild, due to their ranges starting to overlap more. As climate change increases in warmth, maybe we could expect these tow species to merge into a new "hydridized" species or at least these hybrids could form a new species in addition to polar and brown bears. This would probably be a in a decades range, but maybe closer to 100 years or so. </p>
<p>Decreasing amounts of snow cover (decades)</p>

<p>One example might be able to see habitat changes. For example, tropical habitats happening more north or south than expected, since other parts of the world would be warmer than it used to be. This would show up as a recent effect.  </p>
<p>Example 1) Extinction of species- long term</p>

<p><strong>1) Increased vegetation</strong></p>

<p>Warmer temperatures coupled with increased precipitation could lead to greater plant growth around the world. This would likely be a more recent effect.</p>
<p>I agree changes in carbon levels would be an example of the earth getting warmer. </p>

<p>Although I agree, that doesn't have to do with the biosphere unless it is affecting the organisms that live in the water or in coastal areas. </p>
<p>Changes in the observed carbon cycle is another example of how the biosphere is being effected by climate change. This is an example of a more recent effect. </p>

<p>I personally think it is actually somewhat a recent effect too! Species have been going extinct at mass rates, definitely over the course of years rather than centuries as a result of climate change and humans.</p>
<p>Example 2) Increased droughts in drier areas and then increased flooding in other areas. </p>
<p>This is a great example since the drier weather in certain places causes that increased risk of longer and increased wildfires.</p>

<p>An example could be new adaptations arising in populations (and along with that would be a lot of extinction). Adaptions may be something like more heat/humidity tolerance. This would be a long-term effect. </p>
<p>I agree with this. Warmer temperatures and droughts contribute to this issue showing that the earth has gotten warmer. </p>

<p>Increased amounts of Polar bears mating with brown bears. This indicates climate change because the polar bear numbers are drastically decreasing. Additionally the habitat in which they live on the ice is melting so they come farther inland and start mating with other species of bears therefore creating hybrid species. This example could also apply to other animals who are modifying their behavior in order to combat the changes in temperature and habitat. This is a more recent effect of climate change. </p>
<p>I agree with this! </p>
<p>I agree.  This can be a consequence of sea level rising on the biosphere.  There would be much less gene flow and that could cause more risk to certain species. </p>
<p>Good example! I didn't think of that one right away. </p>

<p><strong>2) Decrease in total number of streams and rivers</strong></p>

<p>Higher global temperatures could reduce the amount of snowfall in high altitude regions. This would lead to fewer Spring snowmelt streams</p>

<p>An example of evidence from the biosphere that would show the earth has gotten warmer would be increased species richness throughout the world's ecosystems. When it gets warmer, species can live in newer, previously inhospitable places, and, as a result, would cause an increase in species richness in many areas of the world. </p>
<p>This could be both a long-term and short-term example, depending on the study.</p>

<p>Another change that would be evidence of the earth getting warmer would be changes in migratory patterns of different animals, including birds and butterflies. With the earth getting warmer, they would more than likely migrate later, as a result of it staying warmer for longer.</p>
<p>This would most likely be a short term example.</p>
<p>I didn't think of this and its incredibly true. Same principle for hurricanes.</p>
<p>I touched on this in my post and I don't think many people thought of how habitats would change and how it would affect new incoming species and/or migration patterns.</p>

<p>A change in species habitability could show that the earth is warming. For example in class we talked about the temperature ranges of mosquitos and their fundamental and realized niches. Like every other species, every mosquitos species had a specific temperate tolerance range. If we saw an increase in a mosquitos fundamental niche to areas that were previously too cool to support this species that would suggest the earth is warming. </p>

<p>We have seen the long term effect of this, but we can expect to see an increase in a mosquitos fundamental niche for this example more recently because the Earth has warmed more in the last century than an century before. </p>

<p>- rising sea levels</p>

<p>The increased wildfires are an example of the earth warming that we have seen more recently. The Earth warming has increased the severity of both droughts and storms. In dryer, hotter climates fires are more likely to start and spread. </p>

<p>The rise of extinction would indicate that the earth has gotten warmer. We discussed how organisms can only survive within a specific range of temperature, meaning that if the temperature were to increase beyond that range, it can increase extinction.</p>

<p>One example of possible evidence from the biosphere that would show that the earth has gotten warmer is: </p>

<p>Temperature extremes. Coldest and Warmest days would be significantly warmer. This would be a more recent effect over the next few decades. </p>

<p>- Example 1: Decreasing Glaciers. Recently the glaciers in Greenland have been recorded as melting. This phenomenon has been going on over the last 20 years. Melting rates at these glaciers are the highest they've been over the 10,000 years these glaciers have repeatedly melted </p>

<p>Example 2 - Increase in water vapor in the atmosphere. When the air warms, it can hold more water because the air molecules have a higher entropy( random movement), which opens more space for water molecules to squeeze into. A warmer atmosphere is a response to warming the earth. I would say that this is a decade phenomenon because the increase in CO2 into the atmosphere since the 1800s has caused more sunlight to be trapped in the atmosphere causing the Earth to warm. </p>
<p>California definitely understands this consequence right now. The increase in warmth may lead to more water being evaporated, but a small amount of that will actually precipitate.</p>

<p>Very true. Rising sea levels could cause species to migrate to a different area, leading to more immigration and invasiveness into communities, potentially altering that community's composition. </p>

<p>Long-term: The extinction of some reptile species given the fact that some, like turtles, rely on temperatures for sex determination of their eggs (i.e. warmer eggs become males, cooler eggs become females, or vice versa). If the earth continues warming, over time this may result in a highly unequal ratio of male turtles to female turtles, and eventually they may go extinct. </p>
<p>Short-term: Massive flooding along coastlines is a huge concern if glaciers keep melting and sea levels continue to rise.</p>

<p>I also posted about ice melting and increases in sea levels. I said a short-term effect could be flooding along coastlines, but you're absolutely right that sea level increases could occur over the long term, and it could have an impact on coastline geography.</p>

<p>Forest fires are one possible example of evidence from the biosphere that would show that the earth has gotten warmer. Extinctions can also be due to climate change. These would be considered short-term effects (decades), as scientists estimate that 1/3 of all animal and plant species can be extinct in the next 50 years due to climate change. https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/02/14/climate-change-study-plant-animal-extinction/4760646002/ </p>

<p>Trees respond to higher temperatures, and as a result will get warmer sooner, resulting in a longer growing season. A measurable way to gather evidence for this is to chart when certain deciduous trees begin to grow leaves, and when they shed their leaves. If the growing season is getting measurably longer, then we can say that there is a higher temperature local climate.</p>
<p>Oh, whoops, it's a decades-long event</p>

<p>A centuries-long effect would be to approximate the amount of ice on the planet. This is among the most intuitive ways to indicate that the climate has been getting warmer for centuries. If the amount of land ice in the world is decreasing, then the world is getting collectively warmer.</p>
